title: Life’s a Mess
description: “Life’s a Mess” is a promotional single off of Juice WRLD’s first posthumous studio album   On the track, Juice and Halsey convey their troubles throughout their lives whilst showing appreciation to their desired partners. The track was released four days before the album, and was accompanied by a music video directed by  Chad Ross .

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: Have you ever fallen head over heels for somebody?
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: A frequent topic in Juice’s music, demons, devils, and evil girls often plague his love life. Examples of this can be seen anywhere on his music – from his underground tracks, such as the aptly named tracks “Demon Love“ and “Devil Horns“ – all the way to within his two most popular hits, “Lucid Dreams“ and “All Girls are the Same.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: Not just somebody
No, no
(Rex, you did it again)
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: This is the producer tag for Rex Kudo, who gained popularity after producing Post Malone’s 2016 smash hit, “Go Flex.“ He also informally collaborated with Juice on two unreleased tracks; namely “Life’s a Dungeon“ and “Floor It.“

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: Have you ever fallen head over heels for somebody
That made promises to give you the world? Um
I really hope they held you down
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: Juice and his significant have both struggled to live and love on with past mistakes. An example of this can be seen on his Marshmello-assisted “Come & Go, which released within the same week of this track:Sayin' goodbye to bygones, those are bygonesHead up, baby, stay strong, we gon' live long

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: I really hope it was no lying
'Cause when heart breaks it feel like the world's gone
But if the love's real, you'd feel your soul roar like a lion
And you'd finally let bygones be bygones
Don't throw in the towel, I know it feels like you're the only one trying
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: Contrasting Juice’s normal struggles with toxic and evil girls, this line relates to Juice’s significant other’s positivity. Within a July 2018 interview with MTV News, Juice touched on the number and its significance in his life:999 represents taking whatever ill, whatever bad situation, whatever struggle you’re going through and turning it into something positive to push yourself forward.

lyrics_and_annotations.lyric: You just gotta learn to live and love on
I belong with the one put on this earth for me
lyrics_and_annotations.annotation: Mentioning God and asking Him for help is a recurring theme in Legends Never Die. In the first verse of his 2020 track “Titanic,” off his first posthumous album Legends Never Die, he says something that follows the same idea:They tell me God watchin' over me, I don’t doubt itBut I can see Him gettin' tired of me sinnin' and wildin'Same can be said for the lyrics in the first verse of “Come & Go”:I
